title: What happened to the Viet Cong members after the fall of Saigon? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well,look at these men and women,and you will see.May be to foreigner,they are strange,but most of Vietnamese will know them.  Nguyễn Tấn Dũng - Prime Minister(2006–2016),he was a Vietcong.Born in 1949,Kien Giang,Southern Vietnam. He joined Southern Vietnam Liberation Frontline in 1961 with the role of a medic solider. In 1975, his rank was lieutenant,commander of medic company of Kien Giang Province. [1]  Trương Tấn Sang[2] - Chairman of Vietnam(2011–2016),he was also a Vietcong.Born in 1949 in Long An,Southern Vietnam.Joined Southern Vietnam People Liberation Party in 1969,he worked in student motivation and commanded a guerrilla group in his hometown. In 1971,he was arrested by South Vietnam Government and in 1973 released according to Paris Peace Agreement. His younger sister – Trương Mỹ Hoa was Vice Chairman of Vietnam(2002-2007) also.  Nguyễn Minh Triết[3] - Chairman of Vietnam(2006–2011),born in 1942,Binh Duong Province,Southern Vietnam. In 1960,he joined anti-Diem Government Movement and People's Revolutionary Youth Union. He then worked as an accountant and researcher at the Central Committee of this organization. In 1965,he was admitted to the Southern Revolutionary People's Party and appointed secretary of Youth Union Central Committee in Mỹ Tho Province to 1973.From 1974,he worked as Deputy Head of the Central Youth Union and Deputy Director of the young Volunteers of the Central Union.  Võ Văn Kiệt[4] - Prime Minister(1991–1997),born in 1922,Vĩnh Long Province,Southern Vietnam.Joined in Indochina Communist Party in 1939,he fought with French even before 1945. In 1954,he was First Secretary of Communist Party-Bac Lieu Province.From 1959 to 1970,he is First Secretary is Saigon - Gia Dinh area.From 1973–1975,he was Commissioner of Center Headquarter of Southern Vietnam Liberation Frontline.  Nguyễn Thị Bình [5] ,Vice-Chairman of Vietnam(1992-2002),born in 1927,Sa Đéc Province,Southern Vietnam.She worked for Viet Minh from 1945 in student and women motivation.From 1951,she was arrested and inflicted by French. In 1954,she was released through action of Geneva Accord.From 1960,she was in charge of Foreign Affair of Southern Vietnam Liberation Frontline.From 1968 to 1973,she is the lead of neotigation delegation of Southern Vietnam Liberation Frontline in Paris Peace Neotigation – and she is famous for that.  And the current Prime Minister,Nguyễn Xuân Phúc [6], born in 1954,Quảng Ngãi,Middle Vietnam.He was too young to join Vietcong but his parents and elder sister brother joined. In 1965-1966,a sister of him and his mother was killed in battle .In 1967,he was sent to North to live study there.Vietnam Communist Party is really aware of Vietcong member’s family. In 1954-1955,in action of Geneva Accord, 32.000 sons and daughters of Vietminh’s member in Southern Vietnam evacuated to North [7] .And,yeah,there are situations like Mr.Phuc also. In conclude,there is nothing different between Vietcong’s member and their comrades in the North,they are all under the command of Vietnam Communist Party.There is no discrimination or bad treatment toward Vietcong’s member after the Unification.They joined in and lead the bureaucracy in Southern part.They can reach to highest postion in Government like any one. So, don’t believe what you hear from American and pro-Saigon Puppet Government Traitors,they always potray bad about Vietnam Government. Question: What happened to the Viet Cong members after the fall of Saigon? Answer: Firstly, Well, I think that most of them continued to fight in the Cambodian- Vietnam conflicts from 1975 to 1989. A part of them had to come back home because they were over age for military services.  (Southern Vietnam in the Mekong Delta) Secondly, Many people often made a mistake when trying to divide VC and NVA (North Vietnam). Basically, VC could be considered as the local forces of NVA.  In conclusion: VC are heroes of the Vietnamese who fought for freedom and independence of Vietnam against the American imperialists.
